reviewText:
You may think this game is good at first. You may think that me having clocked in over 200 hours means it must be good. But really, this game is like cocaine. You'll use it once, think it's interesting, then keep going. Soon you'll know it's bad, and that it's just constantly killing you, but you'll keep going, hoping it'll go back to the good it once seemed to be. If you're lucky like me, you'll escape and never play this again.

Let me explain my opinion a little more. This game is essentially an RTS with guns, tanks and artillery. That's fun and fine in itself, at least on paper, but it necessitates a few things. For example, if you have troops with guns, you expect that they'll be able to shoot enemies, and generally get things done without your constant aid. Not in Men of War. Your troops will frequently throw grenades into their own squads, waste ammo shooting at nothing (yeah, you have to keep track of every troop's ammo), miss enemies at point blank range, stare at the last sighted enemy even if they're miles out of range, stop running in favor of standing in a field trying to shoot an invisible sniper, or just flat out do something that makes no sense. This is only the beginning.

Your tanks fare even worse. There is literally no way to use them apart from taking direct control of the tank, the AI for it is that useless. This limits you to having pretty much one tank on the battlefield at a time. This would be reasonable, except that the game's terribly designed engine starts to really kick in now. Even while you desperately try to aim at an enemy vehicle, your shots will typically bounce off, or just flatout prove useless, while later, while not even trying, a .50 cal will destroy the same tank with ease. The game is just littered with inconsistencies, all the while trying desperately to cling to realism. And once again, this is just the beginning.

In trying to move away, so as to hopefully avoid some shots, you'll find that the terrain is just as poorly built. Tanks will simply stop at steep inclines, and will actually become a physics object upon colliding with a rock, juttering out of control for a crucial second or two, regardless of how hard your brushed against it, while it will have no problem pummelling through a block of buildings. Speaking of buildings, some, and it seems more or less entirely random, will never be properly broken and will stay standing even after you've barraged the area with artillery, while some will crumble after a few grenades come near it.

There's also a huge issue with balance, with the Soviets (possibly in accordance with reality) getting not only the best tanks, but also getting them the cheapest. Forget what you've heard about American tanks being cheap, they are the most expensive to field. Germany is the only nation that can compete; Japan and Britain might as well not be playable. In theory, the American infantry is better than the Soviet, but in practice this is only true for basic infantry. Elite infantry finds home with the Soviets again, who pretty much decimate all other units, until you bring in tanks, where once again, the Soviets take the cake. You'd think maybe some artillery would take out them out, but it proves rather fruitless, because they also get very good light vehicles, which will take out whatever artillery you have.

This is all without even getting into the abomination that is the single player mode. The voice acting is cringeworthy; nearly on par with Zelda CDI. The difficulty curves make no sense, ranging from Niagra Falls drops, to brick wall inclines, and there's an extremely shallow learning curve, with the tutorial teaching you only a quarter of what you actually need to know to play effectively. On top of that, the singleplayer AI is completely insane, relying more on fielding impossibly large amounts of units than actually being able to control any.

But I could go on forever. I'm going to cut my time spent with this game short and now try my best never to think of it again. Do yourself a favour and don't ever touch this game.

reviewText:
This is a great game. It has probably about the most realistic gameplay you will ever get from an RTS and it can be very fun to play. Watch out though, although not incredibly complicated it IS a hard game, even more so if you, like me, refuse to play on easy. Ever.
Although the voice-acting is terrible, the graphics are aged and the interface is not to write home about either, making the micromanagement (which is pretty much something you are constantly doing when playing Men of War) a little frustrating at times, the gameplay overall is really good. Also, it makes it all the more rewarding when successfully finishing a mission.

The singleplayer covers 3 campaigns (Soviet, German, Allied), consisting out of 19 missions total, and 5 non-linear bonus missions. As of now, I am busy doing the Soviet one, which will probably take me quite some time to finish, for the missions are really long and hard. The storylines cover some of the less famous battles of WW2, all squad-based.

All in all, if a challenging and realistic (relatively) modern warfare RTS is what you are looking for, you cannot go wrong with Men of War, even more so with the ridiculous price tag of €5,-. Less if you buy it on sale and/or in a package. Men of War is a VERY unique RTS and probably one of the best I ever played.

reviewText: Men of War is one of the gaming industry's biggest accomplishments, settling once of for all the debate of whether games can be considered to be art. Men of War is one of gaming's first autobiographical games which follows the heavy metal band Manowar from their inception during the 1980s. The game has a beautiful opening scene wherein the player controls bassist Joey DeMaio while he snorts the biggest line of cocaine in his life while backstage at a Black Sabbath concert, and neglects to fulfill his duties as a sober fireworks manager. In this sequence the player must complete a series of quick-time-events in order to guide a stumbling Demaio into correctly setting off the fireworks in order to not burn the stage down. During this sequence the quick-time-events get harder to the point where the player cannot complete them, which reveals that Ross the Boss is right beside you and like a true bro, covers over for DeMaio and succeeds in not causing the death of Ronnie James Dio. DeMaio and Ross the Boss become best bros at that moment and start legendary metal band Manowar.\n\nThe rest of the game is a re-tooled version of Activision's Guitar Hero, but all of the songs are from Manowar.

Features

reviewText:
This game is advertised as a real time strategy game, but it's not. It's more like a real time tactics game since you give units specific orders with specific inventories.

Anyway, I can't advise buying this after just playing the first level. I know it's not much, but when:

- Your units won't make decently intelligent decisions on cover fire and throwing grenades at machine gun nests or armored cars while the pause button requires unpausing and selecting new units manually to coordinate orders,
- Your tank randomly doesn't aim or shoot at targets for dozens of seconds at a time while shooting endlessly at other targets until you manually turn the tank a little right before the infantry with a sticky bomb gets right up to the tank (by the way, did I mention that any excess squadmates just sit on your tank while getting shot at and that your tank takes damage just from moving around?),
- The camera angle (not pitch) becomes a pain to handle, and
- Mission objectives require hunting down every last guy in an area rather than those guys engaging you to prevent you from running over their comrades in arms...

...you know this game's bad. People will say that I'm just bad at the game, but the game actually just has really clumsy controls and doesn't respond to them half the time. It reminds me of that stupid Jagged Alliance series.

If you want to play a decent real time tactics game, I'd suggest getting Fallout Tactics.

EDIT: I've played the first mission a second time, and it wasn't as bad. That said, defeating the enemy was rather ridiculous. This time, it didn't respond to my grenade attacks at all, and just let itself get blasted. The enemy had no bazookas, and its AT guns just got wrecked. The hill I had to take was pointless as well since the infantry just rushed my tank which mowed them down with its machine guns, and the convoy either got blasted to bits, or just ran by my tank. It hardly engaged, and the light tanks which did engage hardly damaged my tank even though the tracks got disabled three times. Unlike the first time I played, I was actually able to repair the tracks multiple times as well.

I don't know. The game seems to suffer from black or white thinking with little balance.

reviewText:
Originally posted on March 28, 2011

Men of War is certainly unique. In no other true RTS have I been able to (and indeed required to) manage the inventory of individual soldiers. Each soldier must carry a specific weapon which they may or may not be proficient at using, ammo, a helmet, bandages, and even knives or entrenchment tools. Each vehicle has fuel and ammo which can be replenished, and each seat must be manned by an individual soldier. Combine this with a fairly realistic ballistics and penetration model (infantry are REALLY vulnerable, and certain tanks simply cannot be penetrated by small rounds) and you have some very micro-heavy gameplay with a good degree of realism.

The problem is that the AI is absolutely terrible in single player, and the game pits you against laughably sized hordes of them to compensate for it. While as a history nut I loved the amount of detail and flavor in the vehicles and weapons that were available, the AI and level design undoes almost all of this. The result is a massive amount of save whoring and gamey behavior to exploit the AI. In multiplayer, the variety of units and weaponry is much appreciated, but the gameplay itself is directionless. You can capture points, but nothing you do in game can change the steady stream of points you receive which allow you to unlock more units. The variety of units and size of maps means that there is a hugely wasted opportunity here, because as long as you have the points, you can buy the most advanced tank or infantry unit from the start. There's no hierarchy or sense of progression, and points are seemingly randomly scattered throughout the maps.

Ultimately, Men of War has an appealing level of micro, but fails in terms of direction.

reviewText:
A superb tactical inventory management simulator.

Men of War is at its best when it is exploring the intricacies of men carrying things.  Gripping shuffling-crap-back-and-forth action is, however, occasionally interrupted by other soldiers with different uniforms who show up at random and shoot at your own troops.  The only function of this feature, as far as I can tell, is to deplete your own ammunition; if one of your units dies it's either entirely shruggable or a nigh-mission-failure anyway, so it doesn't matter much.

And ammunition micromanagement is what Men of War excels at.  It's enthralling to send a truck scurrying around the map to scrape up spare machine gun ammunition for your tank which is locked in combat with a large number of enemy soldiers who are unreasonably insistent upon its demise.  There is also tons of pixelhunting fun to be had trying to click on the thing you want to click on, with tension provided by the ever-present possibility of accidentally telling a soldier to take cover on the wrong side of a wall or do something similarly bat-guano stupid.

(I'm not sure why Steam says I don't recommend this game; honestly, it's the best man-to-man cartridge-counting game around.)

A neat little game made for folks who enjoy micromanagement, and like bit more realistic stuffs. You can group your soldiers into groups, but can direct them independently of course. Ah, and all of them have their own inventories with ammo, weapons, grenades, and so forth. So, your average Joe can hold an SMG, an LMG, a rifle, and buttloads of grenades. Okay, it might not be entirely historically accurate, but gives the game some enjoyable moments as you can pick soldiers that will be assigned to special tasks as you take direct control of them - yep, this game has direct control. Press End, and your dreams can come true. It doesn't really work when you have multiple platoons to take care of, but on missions where you have just a small group of soldiers at your disposal, it's awesome. Also, direct controlled tanks are awesome - take aim, and disable enemy tanks' turrets. Enemy soldiers will leave the vehicle, and your MGs can easily take care of them. And then...Grand Theft Wehrmacht happens. Hop in with a single soldier, drive the tank back behind your lines, repair it, put some additional bods into it, and bam, you have a fully functional tank to crush your enemies and see them driven before you. Also, it saves reinforcements - if you are lucky and have some skills, you can finish maps without losing your own tanks and using only looted enemy vehicles.\n\nAnd, it's challenging. Even on Normal you'll have some hard times, if you are not too much into micromanagement, and you aren't a really freakin hardcore strategist. But if you learn the basics, you'll have really good times with this game, and feel growing desire to get each and every one of them. Sadly it lacks proper skirmish where you get a map and battle the AI, but there are enough missions to counter this. Sadly this game was supported by GameSpy, and I'm not sure if you can get it working with Hamachi, but it's worth a try if you and your friends are looking for some WW2 carnage. Especially recommended for wargamers.

This game is a successor to Soldiers: HOWW2 and Faces of War, some brilliant games that rewarded detailed planning, fast reflexes and initiative. They were not made for casuals. And this is why casuals hated them. Too buggy, too hard, uncomprehensible etc etc. Do not hear their whinning if you do not like to just faceroll a stupid AI, but instead you prefer having a challenge. I remember loading same spot like 20 times trying different things so the AI does not steam roll me. Having 3-5 soldiers and having to clear whole bases, kill/capture/disable tanks, escape etc is not something offered by many games.

This is continued in Men Of War. From 2nd mission and on, you will have to face MANY enemies more than you. I checked the end game stats and saw that I was facing like 1000 enemies in defensive missions...and you have like 50 at most. Not to mention the tanks. AI has some nice ability to kill your tanks easier that you can kill its. Yeah this can be frustrating. So, just be more careful. And save often.

Even if you are a veteran of S:HOWW2, some missions can be tough. Although there is no tactics mode like in Faces of War, you can still die easily by some direct shots. I cannot say much about...replayability. Playing 1 mission for 4h +, makes you feel relieved when  you finish it. One thing that I disagree with is that you cannot do as much as you could do in S: HOWW2 when in pause. Having to command MANY squads, resupply their ammo while the AI launches attack after attack is sometimes very demanding. When you have 3-5 soldiers it is easy...no time pressure etc. But the game and its objectives are still viable, and I have screens where I lost like 10 soldiers/0 tanks in defenses. On normal. So, if you plan carefully, think, reload and try different ways to win, you will make it.

Again...it is not for casuals. If you are one, you will cry. If you like tough challenges, then you will love this difficult ♥♥♥♥♥. Graphics are nice. Enough to make take screens of the environment. Voiceovers and sound I do not care. I am muting all games so I can listen to music. Storyline. Again, I do not care much. I just like killing stuff. From what I saw it was there just to exist. Who really cares...

Physics and realism. The stuff I like: explosions, bodies launch at every direction, bullets fear the brave, they disperse, and they change direction when  they hit hard surfaces. Cannon shells...2 types: explosive, armor penetrating. Self explanatory. Now the spotting dot shows you the area of dispersion, the possibility to penetrate and ofc the distance. All this changes according to angle, vehicle armor, its speed, your speed, and other factors. It is the detail that makes the difference, and in this factor the game is a diamond.

Men of War! That's an epic title. This game is the first in a now-longrunning series of real time strategy games. To start off, I must say I will NOT compare to Company of Heroes as it is great in its own right. (I won't be like all of these other fools)

The game's setting is World War II across three campaigns. The Brits in North Africa, the US in Europe, and the Soviets in well... The Soviet Union; eventually moving to Berlin, Germany. I can't really say much about the campaign as I have only played one mission of each. I'm not gonna lie; these missions are pretty hard. You can't go Call of Duty-style run-and-gun across the battlefield! YOUR MEN WILL BE SHOT TO DEATH!! It requires strategy. The same goes for multiplayer.

This game is unique as you have plenty of aspects under your command such as what the soldiers and vehicles carry. Yes, it can get a bit annoying when you have to micromanage everything. I just deal with it. Another neat thing is 'Direct Control' where you can take control of a soldier's or vehicle's main weapon. But this game is not without its cons. The game looks very dated. It looks ugly, but that doesn't affect the game itself.

To close, I recommend this game to anyone who's looking for a challenge. If you need a good strategy game to play on the side, here it is.

One of my all time favorite strategy games.

First, THE BAD:
The Voice Acting - Id rather be listening to Nickelback.

Learning curve - Second mission puts you in control of over 50 men. It's not noob friendly. This is a drawback for some but it's rewarding succeed in this game.

Minor Gliches - Nothing game breaking but it's no StarCraft 2.

Here's The Good:
Direct control - allows you to take control of a specific unit (anything from a tank to a sniper).

Realistic Tank Combat system - Seriously... it's amazing. The shot penetration depends on the angle, armor thickness, round size, and distance. This makes for some awesome in game moments where you can take out multiple Panzer III with a single KV-1.

Old School Inventory system - This is a downside for some but I love having to drop ammo into each soldier, loading up tanks by dragging Shells from one unit to the other. It would be nice it there was a more steamlined way of doing this but being able to salvage higher teir weapons with extra riflemen can make all the difference in a mission.

Dynamic Destruction - Huge explosions as well as craters and fully distructable buildings. What more do you need?

Mission Veriaty - From huge frontline assults to night raids, this game has something for all.

Don't take my word for it, try out the demo.

I want to like this game...

Deep micro management and realism. Horrible voice acting. Ancient graphics. It has everything of a classic RTS game.

But HOLY COMMUNIST is it difficult!! And not even because of the gameplay! No, the clunky interface and complete morons recruited to your side of the battle make the game unbeatable in itself. Think Mike Tyson Punch Out, except you can't punch. Troops don't shoot, but they'll kill each other, stop running randomly when under fire, and this is all your squad! The enemy is a cold-hard  killing machine.

I played the first Russian mission a dozen times before beating it. My biggest advice is to take it slow when the game allows. Make use of the manual control (I almost exclusively use it to be honest. The AI shoots well, but only when they feel like actually shooting.) and don't even keep playing. You'll just keep getting upset.   I know the cake tastes good, but its laced with an addictive poison.

I only PASS it because it is a complete game that is enjoyable for RTS fans.

This game is actually pretty good. There's alot of unit variation and serves its role as a WWII game well. This is very different from most RTS games, as enemies drop armour, bandages, ammo and guns, so you can command units to loot dead corpses.

Tanks are very powerful, like they were in WWII, seemingly unstoppable.

However, this game is very hard, I ended up getting a refund because it was so hard. Before buying this, finish the demo version. I played on easy mode and it seemed impossible. This was also the first mission, 4th objective.

Its overall very good, but really hard.

Combine a solid single-player experience with in-depth stratagey gameplay that almost reaches RPG-levels of inventory managment, and the fact that this game is a modern classic as it was the first Men of War game (which is now a large series), this game is great. IF you prefer larger scale battles with a little less micro-managment, I would recommend Men of War Assault Squad 2. However, if you're looking for a solid single player game and don't want to bother with the rather excellent and always expanding Steam workshop for Assault Squad 2 (one of the best communities of developers out there), give the original Men of War a shot.
